site.title: Nordum - A Pan-Scandinavian Language
site.description: A unified written language designed to be understood by speakers of Norwegian, Danish, and Swedish

language_specification.nordum_definition: Nordum is a constructed pan-Scandinavian written language designed to maximize mutual intelligibility between Norwegian (Bokmål), Danish, and Swedish while maintaining systematic regularity and practical modern usage.
language_specification.equal_respect_desc: Respects all three source languages equally without favoring any single tradition
language_specification.regional_accommodation_desc: Accommodates pronunciation differences through alternative spellings
language_specification.modern_practicality_desc: Integrates modern practicality with English loanword preservation
language_specification.systematic_regularity_desc: Maintains systematic regularity while supporting linguistic variation
language_specification.transparency_desc: Provides transparency in all linguistic decision-making
language_specification.native_speakers_desc: Norwegian, Danish, and Swedish speakers seeking a shared written standard
language_specification.developers_desc: Building tools and applications for Scandinavian communication
language_specification.balanced_selection_desc: Equal respect for all three source languages with strategic selection for optimal clarity
language_specification.norwegian_swedish_systematic: Norwegian/Swedish over Danish for systematic inflection
language_specification.english_integration_desc: Modern technical terms preserved unchanged following established Scandinavian practice
language_specification.morphological_distinctions_desc: Each grammatical category has distinctive endings to prevent confusion and enable clear parsing
language_specification.regular_numbers_desc: Use the most regular decimal system to eliminate complexity
language_specification.question_words_rule: Eliminate silent H, use clear v- pattern with pronunciation variants
language_specification.distinctive_endings_desc: Each grammatical category has distinctive endings to eliminate ambiguity and improve parsing
language_specification.verb_er_rule: All verbs in present tense end in -er, never -ar. Clear distinction from noun plurals which always end in -ar.
language_specification.noun_ar_rule: All noun plurals end in -ar, never -er. Clear distinction from verb present tense which always ends in -er.
language_specification.perfect_cognates_desc: Words identical across all three languages
language_specification.divergent_forms_desc: When all three languages differ, select most systematic
language_specification.alternatives_philosophy: Nordum supports both Scandinavian vowel traditions as valid alternatives, accommodating different pronunciation preferences while maintaining systematic consistency.
language_specification.uses_ae_o_tradition: Uses æ/ø following Norwegian and Danish orthographic tradition
language_specification.familiar_to_norwegian_danish: Familiar to Norwegian and Danish speakers
language_specification.uses_a_o_tradition: Uses ä/ö following Swedish and German orthographic tradition
language_specification.morphological_consistency_desc: Alternative spellings don't affect grammatical endings
language_specification.recognition_over_production_desc: All forms recognized, one form recommended for learning
language_specification.user_choice_desc: Individuals can choose preferred spelling system

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.subtitle: Answers to common questions about Nordum
faq.whatIsNordumAnswer: Nordum is a constructed pan-Scandinavian written language designed to serve as a common written standard for Scandinavian communication in the modern world. It aims to maximize mutual intelligibility between Norwegian (Bokmål), Danish, and Swedish while maintaining systematic regularity and practical modern usage.
faq.whyCreatedAnswer: Nordum was created in response to several modern realities:
faq.changingLandscape: Changing linguistic landscape: English has increasingly become the main language of international communication, while Scandinavian languages are used to a smaller degree in global contexts
faq.geographicMobility: Geographic mobility: People travel more frequently across Scandinavia, creating a need for easier cross-border communication
faq.digitalCommunication: Digital communication: The internet and digital platforms require simple, consistent language standards
faq.replacementQuestion: Is Nordum meant to replace existing Scandinavian languages?
faq.replacementAnswer1: Absolutely not. Nordum is not designed to forbid or replace the current written languages (Norwegian, Danish, Swedish). Instead, it provides an additional option for those who wish to use a common Scandinavian standard to make communication easier across national borders.
faq.replacementAnswer2: The goal is to allow for the usage of Nordum as a supplementary written language that enables Scandinavians to communicate without having to change language every few kilometers when traveling across the region.
faq.nynorskRelationship: How does Nordum relate to Nynorsk?
faq.nynorskAnswer1: Nordum takes a different approach than Nynorsk, which was created in the 19th century as part of the Norwegian nationalist movement. Nynorsk was specifically designed to separate from Danish and Swedish influences as much as possible, drawing heavily from rural Norwegian dialects.
faq.nynorskAnswer2: In contrast, Nordum embraces the common Scandinavian heritage and aims to bridge the languages rather than separate them. Where Nynorsk sought distinction, Nordum seeks connection and mutual intelligibility.
faq.historicalContext: What is the historical context of Scandinavian languages?
faq.historicalAnswer1: Historically, the Scandinavian languages formed a dialect continuum where neighboring dialects were mutually intelligible. The modern standardized languages emerged through separate standardization processes:
faq.danishStandardization: Danish: Standardized through administration and Luther's Bible translation
faq.swedishStandardization: Swedish: Developed through state administration and literature
faq.norwegianStandardization: Norwegian: Evolved through both Danish influence (Bokmål) and nationalist movements (Nynorsk)
faq.historicalAnswer2: Nordum recognizes this shared heritage and creates a modern written standard that honors all three traditions while providing practical utility for contemporary communication needs.
faq.internationalCompanies: International companies operating in multiple Nordic countries
faq.travelers: Travelers and expatriates living in Scandinavia
faq.learningDifficulty: Is Nordum easy to learn for Scandinavian speakers?
faq.learningAnswer: Yes! Nordum is designed to be immediately accessible to speakers of any Scandinavian language. The lexical selection prioritizes words that are already familiar across all three languages, and the grammatical system simplifies many of the irregularities found in the individual languages.
faq.englishLoanwords: How does Nordum handle English loanwords?
faq.englishAnswer: Nordum preserves English loanwords for technical and modern terms where they are already widely used across Scandinavia. This reflects the reality of modern Scandinavian communication where English terms are commonly integrated, particularly in technology, business, and academic contexts.
faq.contribution: How can I contribute to Nordum?
faq.contributionAnswer1: Nordum welcomes contributions from linguists, developers, and Scandinavian language speakers. You can:
faq.reportIssues: Report issues or suggest improvements via GitHub Issues
faq.technicalHelp: Help with technical development or documentation
faq.contributionAnswer2: See the Contributing Guide for more detailed information.
faq.communityInvolvement: How can I get involved with the Nordum community?
faq.communityAnswer1: The Nordum project thrives on community involvement. Here's how you can participate:
faq.githubIssues: GitHub Issues: Report bugs, suggest features, or ask questions through our issue tracker
faq.emailCollaboration: Email: Reach out to us directly for collaboration opportunities
faq.discussion: Discussion: Join conversations about language design and implementation
faq.testing: Testing: Help test new features and provide feedback
faq.communityAnswer2: We believe in open collaboration and welcome all forms of constructive contribution to make Nordum the best possible pan-Scandinavian communication tool.

purpose.title: Purpose
purpose.description: Nordum aims to create a written standard that maximizes mutual intelligibility between Norwegian, Danish, and Swedish speakers while maintaining the rich linguistic heritage of Scandinavia.

philosophy.title: Philosophy
philosophy.description: By identifying common linguistic patterns and selecting the most widely understood forms, Nordum seeks to reduce barriers to communication across Nordic borders.

vision.title: Vision
vision.description: A future where Scandinavians can communicate in writing without having to use English, fostering greater cultural and economic cooperation.

orthography.title: Orthographic Simplification
orthography.description: Nordum adopts the most phonetically consistent spelling patterns common across the three languages, eliminating silent letters where possible.
orthography.example: Example: "hus" (house) - consistent across all three languages

morphology.title: Unified Morphology
morphology.description: Verb conjugations and noun declensions follow the most regular patterns found in the source languages, prioritizing clarity and simplicity.
morphology.example: Example: Regular verb ending "-er" for present tense (han arbeider - he works)

lexicon.title: Lexical Selection
lexicon.description: When variants exist, Nordum chooses words that are most widely recognized across all three languages, or creates transparent compounds.

syntax.title: Syntactic Harmony
syntax.description: Word order follows the most common patterns, typically Subject-Verb-Object with V2 word order in main clauses.
syntax.example: Example: "I dag arbetar jag" (Today work I = Today I work)
